title: Possession and noun modifiers
introduction: Do you know how to use noun modifiers or different possessive forms? Test what you know with interactive exercises and read the explanation to help you.
rules: We use apostrophes to show that something belongs to a person or an animal.
keyPoints: we're talking about a place or group made up of people
the words expressing units here are singular, not plural
examples: Do you know how to use noun modifiers or different possessive forms?
We don't usually use 's with things.
We normally use of to talk about position or to say which part of something we are referring to.
Sometimes, both 's and of are possible.
In these cases, it is a matter of the writer's or speaker's preference in that particular context.
Or they can show that one thing is a part of something else.
Measurements, ages and values can also be used as noun modifiers.
